Blog.post: Spartacus AKA "Sparty the Party Boy"
Lordin' over the doggies... (Photo taken last year)
That's Varinia, peeking from behind the laptop...
Tabitha. And the true love of Newby's.
Cleo sitting in the overgrowth in our backyard.
Tiger, my pretty boy.
I love those words. I have hundreds of books on my "To Be Read" bookcase.

Look what I got from Kathy for my birthday! As you can see, it fits perfectly with my new easy chair/ottoman set (which arrived last week after a 12-week wait!!). This is a closeup of the fabric for the set: I love my chair, ottoman and the lamp! Thanks to the comfy chair and the reading lamp, I'm reading a lot more these days. Hm, I think you can see Mousehole and her white paws peeking from behind the chair...
Cleo in the backyard, resting.
Spartacus, a dedicated squirrel watcher...
I took this pic in pitch-black darkness and the result is brilliant. A closeup of the mums.

Cleo gazing intently across the backyard. As the backyard is always bustlin' with small animals such as possums, moles, chipmunks and squirrels, especially in the overgrowth, I can never get her attention as long as we're on the backyard deck.
Our front porch. Best place to be during spring and autumn days. That is, when Newby isn't smoking his beloved cigars in front of me.
He's provoking Cleo into a barking fit by mugging faces at her.
Varinia, up to her tricks again...
Driving by the "altered" NYC skyline...
Don't ask me why, but this was my very first sight of the NH State Capitol ever...
The oval window in our room at Bloomsbury Bed and Breakfast, in Easthampton, MA.
Driving over urlLink Tappan Zee Bridge . It was taken through the windshield and it came out pretty good.
Just had to get rid of pre-travel nerves...
Before Tiger was sitting in my chair and relaxing on a hot, lazy Sunday afternoon... But now Tiger's all bug-eyed and no longer relaxed because I vacuumed too close to the chair, oops.
Ugh, it's so hot out... Poor Cleo languishing on the backyard deck in the 95-degree weather. Yep, that's birdy doodoo next to my baby!
Nothing like a great book and great pasta for lunch at the mall after shopping.
My sweet baby, Miss Mousehole, enjoying the morning sun. The pic was taken with the camera sitting on the floor, so she was looking at it, not at me or you!
I thought a black-and-white kitty snoozing in that chair would be a nice touch for this photo, but urlLink Miss Mousehole would think none of it. :-/
An insect-eating plant, in happier days. Mousehole killed it this morning.
My little girl, Varinia. The smallest, the lightest, and the sweetest of all.

I woke up at 6:30 in time for my LSD (long slow distance)...to a truly gorgeous morning, so I just had to go sit out on the backyard deck and just space out for a few minutes. When it looked like Newby was sleeping for a little while longer, I got a cup of coffee and sunbathed for a few minutes. I enjoyed the feel of warm sun rays mixed in with licks of cold air on my shoulders. Then, reluctantly, I had to get up and go walk. At least, it was a perfect walking weather.
Tabitha and her reflective eyes.
...change colors already!
...a clean and sparkling kitchen. :-) I do so love my kitchen. It's a perfect place to be at early in the morning when it's too chilly outside. Note the sun dancing on the refrigerator.
Spartacus enjoying the beautiful autumn morning...

Driving along the Virginia countryside... This building stands at the beginning of a village that is only one block long. Newby persuing wine list in the foyer room while we wait for our table. Happy Thanksgiving! The drive back home The photo doesn't do justice to the beauty of the countryside Sunset back at home... Hope you all had a nice holiday!

When Cleo was a puppy, she used to bark at the camera all the time so we could never get good photos of her...but now she just barely *tolerates*, as you can see in her face, hehe. Hard to believe she'll be 10 in January!
urlLink This week's challenge at urlLink PhotoFriday.com ... Olive oil and red wine vinegar

urlLink Tiger and Mousehole love to lay on the ottoman, however, one of them can only be on it or there'll be a catfight. But just for me, they grudgingly posed together for this photoblog. A second or two after this photo was snapped, claws suddenly came out and I had to chase them off the ottoman. Heh!
urlLink What a way to start the summer season...

urlLink When I let Cleo outside, she immediately captured a huge dragonfly that was hovering on our deck. I never ever noticed the insect, and I was so aghast that I made Cleo release it from her mouth. It was still alive but panting hard in the sun, so I brought it out of the sun into the dark overgrowth.

urlLink A finished cross stitch kit. I started it last fall after receiving an order from a scrapbooker wanting a cover for her Halloween album. I was to finish it on December 1st, but I was sidelined by injury and holiday plans and wasn't able to finish it until now. Of course, the scrapbooker is no longer interested in it. I'll probably put it up for sale at eBay in the end, but for now, I just want to hold on to it and enjoy it. It was such a fun project.

urlLink I have to sweep dead cicadas off the front porch every morning before I can sit and relax with my book. We're lucky we're not exactly swarmed with them this time because there has been so much development around here (new subdivision, new school, new hospital, new metro station, and new bypass) over the last 17 years.
urlLink In case you can't figure out what the photo is about, that's Miss Mousehole covering her delicate nose with her dainty white mitten. She always sleeps in this way, for some reason.

urlLink I collect vintage Alfred Mainzer Dressed Animals postcards. I prefer the Belgium #4850-4998 series, which were printed in the 1940's and 1950's. I first discovered these postcards while surfing on eBay back in January of 2001 and immediately fell in love with them. By early last year, my collection of 148 postcards was complete...except for the postcard numbered #4897. For some reason, the Belgium postcard had never shown up on eBay, though the other series of the same postcard is not so rare. So two weeks ago, I paid a visit to the Mainzer postcards page on eBay and my heart stopped when I realized the auction was from the Belgium series. To make sure, I emailed the seller to see if the postcard was really printed in Belgium and she assured me it was. I then won it via the last-second sniping. It arrived in the mail over the weekend, and now my collection is officially complete.
urlLink My sweet boy Tiger grabbing some early-morning rays in the kitchen... urlLink ...and then my darling little girls, Cleo and Mousehole enjoying the mid-morning sunburst between clouds.

urlLink I found the figurine of the Blessed Virgin Mary and Baby Jesus in our backyard while mowing the lawn soon after we moved into our house back in 1988. It was dirty after being half buried, and the top of her halo and her feet had been broken off, but I couldn't make myself toss it into the trash bin. I also had no idea how to dispose of it properly, so I just stuck it in the silverware drawer. After 16 years, it's still there.
urlLink Taken last Monday. It'd been raining all day, and as dusk was about to arrive, there was a sudden spurt of sun. It was so bright that one could see it reflected on those leaves.
urlLink Next goal: finish the cats!
urlLink Miss Mousehole "helping" Daddy pack his stuff for his summer job...

urlLink That's where Newby will be working this summer. It's really a very pretty campus and all the buildings on it are stonehouses. urlLink At Newby's aunt and uncle's house. Like Cleo, Cosic has her own sofa. Like Cleo, Cosic does not tolerate cameras very well.
urlLink Back from the library.

urlLink Every Monday, I'll post a WIP (work in progress) photo of my current cross stitch project. I need something to get me going...I go 3, 4, 5 days without touching it. THAT'S NOT GOOD! Finished the window sill and panes. Next goals: flowers, plants, doily and sideboards. Here's the model: urlLink

urlLink Cleo and I looooooooooove sitting in the new chaise lounge. For a princess, Cleo can be incredibly filthy. With that in mind, when I'm not using the lounge, I flip the cusion over to the "wrong" side (translation: dirty and soiled from her past uses) to protect my "right" side (clean, of course!) from her use. However, I left the lounge for a few seconds (just to grab a Diet Coke from the refrigerator) without flipping the cushion and when I returned, Cleo was already on it. Then I recalled that a few minutes earlier, she had been busy rubbing "stench" (ya know, from wild animals...) all over her fur on the grass. Can we say, "EEEEWWWWWWWW!" Now I gotta clean the cushion and dry it in the sun for a few hours. There goes my blissful afternoon of reading. Grr.

urlLink Well, Sparty was stuck under the bed AGAIN this morning. I was so maaaddd! I'm aching all over from the strenous activity of dismantling the KING-SIZED bed yesterday. I didn't sleep well last night because of the pain, so I decided that if there was going to be the dismantling again, Newby would do it, as soon as he came home from wherever. Sparty would be fine where he was...it wasn't that life-threatening. So there. I showered and dressed, unloaded the dishwasher, popped in a load of wash, and straightened out the family room. And fed Cleo, Tiger, and Mousehole, and prepared three dishes with meds for the older kitties. When the dishes were ready, I let the older kitties in. Guess who came in first? Sparty! He managed to unstuck himself all by himself. For food, not for me!

urlLink Sparty almost scared me to death this morning! I realized he was missing at feed time this morning. Come to think of it, I didn't see him last night either when I went to bed! I did not want to stress Newby out in case it was unnecessary (he had some important appointments today that he couldn't miss) so I waited until he left and then started looking for the darn cat. As a last resort, I started looking under all the beds though I knew he wouldn't fit under any of them because he is a big baby and weighs over 30 lbs. I finally found him under one of the guest beds, totally stuck. I had to dismantle the bed so I could release him. Poor baby...he peed for a long time and then gulped his food. He's doing fine now. I'm such a bad mommy! :-(
urlLink urlLink Darn. Who knew?

urlLink We opted to stay home and watch the funeral procession on TV rather than travel to DC and be "touched by history"...though we only live across the river from DC, we've learned from many years of experience that it's better to stay home if you want the "front-row view" of an occasion/event, so... President Reagan was the one who had the greatest impact on where I am today... I was RIF'ed (reduced in force) from my first Federal government job (1981), worked for the Peace Corps in the Philippines for two years (1982-1984), got a job offer to work at the Pentag0n (1985), but let go due to a "poor performance review" *long story* (1986), got another job under a "Schedu1e A" (disability) program (1987) and then lost it due to a conflict of interest *another long story* (1989). Yet, I'm very, very grateful for this quirky direction that led to my present happiness.

urlLink Seeing those kitties like this warms my heart in a bittersweet way because I know this moment is so fleeting. Besides being elderly, between them they have arthritis, blindness, diabetes, heart murmur and obesity. My babies.
urlLink Birthday Girl Varinia urlLink Birthday Boy Spartacus

urlLink This is Lia, an adorable Tonkinese belonging to a vacationing couple we are friends with. So far, she's doing all the stuff that I've trained my own kitties not to do so. Sliding paws under the bedsheets in a playful way is the worst...apparently, Lia likes to "bury" her toys under the sheets. And, oh my gosh, but she PROWLS at night. She'll be with us until August 16th...so far, I've had nothing but sleepless nights and endless fetch games every night. Because Varinia and Mousehole, who are dominant types do not appreciate intruders, Lia has to stay in our bedroom behind a closed door. I do so love her hazel eyes though...

urlLink Tabitha's sounds (heart, lungs, etc.) are still normal. But the vet did point out that her left paw seems quite crooked from arthritis. Other than that, Tabitha is doing pretty good for her age...she's 16.
urlLink Being declawed (he came to us like that), Tiger is excluded from the kitties' monthly visits to the vet's to have their claws clipped.
urlLink A 3-D birthday card I got from my sister Kathy. It has the things I love...cats, books, crafts, etc. There are seven cats, which is what I have IRL. Too cute!

urlLink The back yard. urlLink The front yard. Being a "tree-hugger", this is always a very traumatic time for me. However, being in a near-tropical climate, it's a necessity if we want to keep ants and other pests away from the house.

urlLink I took out the bow that the orange tabby was wearing in the model. Why cross stitch designers always put those ridiculous bows on cats, I don't know, but they don't wear them in real life! Though the kit doesn't ask for much backstitching, you can tell from this photo that it badly needs it. I'm now working on the blue valance, so will post another photo as soon as I finish it.

urlLink Today marks five whole years since we lost Tabitha's sister, Sable... Tabitha is sitting behind a needlepoint pillow. It was given to Newby in 1982 after his cat, Samantha was put to sleep. Like Tabitha and Sable, Samantha was a Sealpoint Siamese. Except for the six years between Samantha's death in 1982 and our adoption of Tabitha and Sable in 1988, Newby has never been without a Sealpoint Siamese or two his whole life. His grandmother was the one who instilled in Newby a love of these cats. She was in the habit of adopting pairs. So Newby grew up with two pairs of Sealpoint Siameses. The first pair was Lucifer and Tinkerbell. Tinkerbell was run over by a car at a very young age, and Lucifer lived to be about 25 years old. Though Lucifer has been gone since the 1960's, the family still talks about him. The second was Samantha and Scarlet O'Hara. Scarlet O'Hara was put down at age 9 after she was bitten by some wildlife, and Samantha lived to 17 years old.

urlLink A while ago I read in a cross stitching forum about needlecraft mystery paperbacks. I rarely read mysteries anymore, but I was very, very intrigued by them. So when Newby said he was heading to the library, I asked him to check out one of these books so I could see whether I'll like it or not. Well, he brought home the ENTIRE series!! :-/ I have to admit they look really interesting. Oh well, you know my plans for this week! :-) *adjusting and patting the cushioning on my deck lounge*

urlLink Taken at breakfast this morning. Always the very first in the kitchen at breakfast, I couldn't interest her with her dish for a while. Our backyard has really been taken over by wildlife, providing fascinating entertainment for our furkids... All the greenery in our backyard is all swollen and lush from the many torrential rains we've had lately this summer.
We're expecting a hot and humid 4th of July holiday weekend! Stay in a cool and dark room. Keep hydrated. Turn on the air conditioning. Stay away from the direct sun. >^..^ ^..^
urlLink On a hot and humid day like today, Varinia likes to cool off on our glass coffee table in the living room...

urlLink It contains the full DMC 472-skein floss set. It was a steal at only $110, rather than the $.55 per skein = $259.60 that the local needlework shop normally sells. And the priority shipping was free. I ordered the set in a hissy fit after finding a great chart, only to find out I was out two colors.
